Here is an interesting fact. You can apply any function with a Taylor series to a matrix. And if the matrix A can be expressed by A = P^-1 D P where D is diagonal (I.E. all eigenvalues are unique), then f(A) = P^-1 f(D) P where f(D) is a diagonal matrix of of the function f applied to the values of D. The reason is simple when you look at A^2 = (P^-1 D P) (P^-1 D P) = P^-1 D^2 P since P P^-1= I. If A doesn't have unique eigenvalues, it gets a little trickier. We can use the Jordan form A = P^-1 J P = P^-1 (D+N) P where D is diagonalized and N is nilpotent with the same order as the algebraic multiplicity of A (let's call that n). And the Taylor series of N would have a n terms, which in most cases is finite. I'd like to add that there's another way to visualize how e^{At} gives you the evolution when A is the derivative (in the sense dx/dt = A x), which is based on the other well-known relation involving e: e^x = lim_{n->inf} (1 + x/n)^n . First, note that this is also valid when x is a matrix! Let's use A*t. Then, if we look at n=1, we have  e^{At} ~ 1 + At  , which multiplied by the initial state x(t=0) will give us a very crude approximation to x(t)  (since A is the derivative, and in the limit t->0 that's what it means!). Now, for n=2, e^{At} ~ (1+At/2)(1+At/2) , which can be seen as using the derivative to take us to an intermediate point at t/2, and then again from that point to t/2 later. That is a better approximation to x(t). You see where this is heading... n->inf will be like using the derivative infinite times to make infinitesimal (dt ~ t/n) update steps of the original x(0)... which gives x(t). Hope you like it :)
